title: hulk fancy dress party prank
story: The hilarious prank played out in a Durham pub after Anthony Gardiner decided to go as his favourite angry superhero.He donned a green bodysuit complete with padded muscles and painted his face to look like the comic book character.A video captures the moment he turns up to discover he is the only one in fancy dress.Just to twist the kne, the group posted the video online so the whole nation could have a chuckle at the prank.Anthony told Chronicle Live: I felt like a right idiot as I walked in.The story has a happy ending – with Gardiner not paying for a drink all night.He said: After a few, I started to feel less of an idiot.I took some photos with some kids who loved the outfit and everyone  in town, including myself, seemed to see the funny side.Colleagues Yak Williams and Mark Blackburn had come up with the idea for their Christmas outing – even pretending to dress as Batman and Robin to allay suspicion.The friend who filmed the stunt told Chronicle Live: I think he secretly loved it!

title: eu chief jean claude juncker mps dont trust theresa may
story: The EU Commission chief issued the extraordinary diplomatic breach as he also slammed the government’s handling on Brexit, telling it: “Get your act together”.His broadside came as it also emerged last night that two weeks of talks to try to improve Theresa May’s Brexit deal have failed to produce a breakthrough.The PM has just nine days to go to win enough concessions on the hated Irish backstop to persuade Tory MPs to back her when the Commons debates it again.But Whitehall sources admitted last night that while officials in Brussels are still talking, there has been “no signicant progress”.Mr Juncker’s latest rant is a bitter blow to No, who had been pinning their hopes on the commission president to broker an addition to the agreement.It also comes two weeks after his ugly confrontation with Mrs May at a Brussels summit when he dubbed her “nebulous”.In an interview with German newspaper Die Welt, he said: “It is not us who are leaving the United Kingdom - it is the United Kingdom that is leaving the European Union.“I find it entirely unreasonable for parts of the British public to believe that it is for the EU alone to propose a solution for all future British problems.“My appeal is this: get your act together and then tell us what it is you want. Our proposed solutions have been on the table for months.”The former Luxembourg PM added: “I have the impression that the majority of British MPs deeply distrust both the EU and Mrs May.“It is being insinuated that our aim is to keep the United Kingdom in the EU by all possible means. That is not our intention.”Hitting back last night, a No source said: “What does he hope to achieve by saying this  I don’t know whose interests that serves”.Tory MP Nigel Huddleston dubbed it “not particularly useful or helpful language”, adding: “It is inappropriate but not surprising, as he is under pressure from European businesses to produce a deal as well”.Mrs May has been told by Tories and the DUP to seek legally binding assurances that the backstop that keeps Britain in the customs union will be time-limited.One senior aide to the PM last week dubbed Mr Juncker the UK’s “best hope” of finding a fix as he was “put on this earth to negotiate”.The new row came as International Trade Secretary Liam Fox yesterday warned that the chances of Britain leaving the EU would be down to  Mrs May’s deal is voted down in two weeks time.It also emerged that senior Tory and Labour MPs are planning to force the government to delay Brexit by three monthsthe Commons throws out the deal.It was claimed that cross-party talks have been underway for several weeks to ensure the March  date is put back until July in a bid to win the government more time.Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn today accuses Theresa May and her ministers of tipping Britain “into crisis” for leaving the country with no deal with the EU in place with just  days to go today until Brexit takes place.In his New Year message, the Opposition boss attacked the Tories for “the complete mess they’ve made of Brexit, trying to drive through a bad deal and letting people down all across the country whether they voted leave or remain.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady vote 2018 mega year women
story: I don’t know about you but I can’t even pretend I’m going to be sad to see the back of .In fact, it’s fair to say it was pretty much an annus ­horribilis.We have spent the year ­watching the country unravel in a slow, disastrous free-fall, unable to work out how the heck we are going to achieve anything even remotely ­resembling a “good” Brexit.And it’s still not clear.The reality is that we can all speculateuntil the cows come home.Sure, it might be a bit like the Millennium Bug in , when people were ­certain we would go into techno-meltdown on the stroke of midnight, only to wake up to a world that was exactly the same.Then again, there might be dficulties in post-Brexit Britain that haven’t even ­occurred to us yet.The truth is, we don’t know what le is going to be like after Brexit — and that’s scary.My husband Paul, who has an Italian passport, said the other day: “After Brexit, am I going to be able to stay in this country ”And I realised the answer to that is . . . who knows This year hasn’t all been bad news.Interest rates are still low, so people can pay their ­mortgages.But when people lack confidence about the future, they stop spending.No one likes uncertainty, and the more uncertain things are, the less people are inclined to make any sudden moves.There are other good things about this year too.In some respects,  has been the year of the woman.What started in October  with the beginning of the #MeToo movement has snowballed into women being increasingly likely to demand — and receive — more equality and more respect.This was the year a spotlight was shone into the dark corners of the gender pay gap, with employers with  or more staff being made to publish their figures comparing men and women’s average pay gap across their firm.It’s much harder to justy a pay gap that’s out in the open, so this is the beginning of real change.It is also  years since women got the vote, which is something to celebrate.And this year saw the first statue of a woman — the suffragist ­Millicent Fawcett — erected in Parliament Square. About time too. But still, it’s progress.And there is no doubt that ­attitudes to women are changing.We’ve got a second female Prime ­Minister and a female playing the lead in Doctor Who.And women are rising up. We are organising, ­protesting, shaming and building power.We are making the women’s movement central to everyone’s conversation. Women are finding their voice.And the most important thing is we are getting heard.We are not going to accept mansplaining or being ­spoken down to “stupid woman”.Feminism is the word of the year, with more and more women standing up for themselves and demanding equality, and I predict that process is going to continue in .Now that I think about it, there were other good things about .It was the year we rediscovered hope in football during the World Cup.We did better than we thought we would — and it’s not often we can say that.The England team and manager Gareth Southgate restored our ­national self-esteem and gave us something to cheer about when there really was not much .The World Cup showed us nice guys can win.Sure, we didn’t bring home the trophy but it’s fair to say Gareth Southgate’s a winner in everyone’s eyes.And it’s not over yet:  is the women’s football World Cup — so that’s something to look forward to with hope.Hope is an important word. And now, more than ever, we need to find a way to hang on to the things that make us feel optimistic about the future.There were other hopeful things about .This was the year that gave us the breath of fresh air that is Meghan Markle — and it also saw the most stylish royal wedding this country has probably ever seen.Meghan was a signier of change for the Royal Family, which needed to modernise.And while I know some people have decided she is “pushy”, or criticise her for her relationship with her father, I think Meghan is one of the best things that has ever happened to our royals.We also had a royal baby — Prince Louis — and now we have another one on the way, which is happy news.My personal highlight of  was having lunch at Buckingham Palace with the Queen.It really was a wonderful occasion, spending intimate time talking to such an inspiring woman.And now here we are, poised on the brink of .I’m not a New Year’s Eve ­person. title: 13m contract emergency brexit ferries
story: NewsBrexit: £m contract for emergency ferries handed to firm with NO SHIPSThe government contract was given to Seaborne Freight despite the fact it has no services runningShareCommentsByAndrew WoodcockMark Chandler:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsExtra ferries are meant to ease pressure on Dover "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pound.million Government contract to run emergency ferries in the event of a no-deal Brexit has been handed to a company which currently operates no ships. Seaborne Freight was one of three companies awarded contracts totalling poundm last week, tasked with laying on extra crossings to ease pressure on Dover. It wants to run freight ferries from Ramsgate to Ostend in Belgium, starting with two ships in late March and increasing to four by the end of the summer. But a Conservative county councillor for the Kent port said it wasnt believe possible to set up a new service from Ramsgate by the scheduled Brexit date of March .   Councillor Paul Messenger questioned the contract, telling the BBC: It has no ships and no trading history so how can due diligence be done  Why choose a company that never moved a single truck in their entire history and give them pound million  I dont understand the logic of that. Seaborne was set up two years ago and has been in negotiations about running freight ferries between Ramsgate and Ostend, but no services are currently running. And narrow berths in the port mean there are few suitable commercial vessels available. In a statement, the company said it had been working since  on plans to reintroduce ferry sailings from Ramsgate from early .   The business has been financed by the shareholders during a development phase involving locating suitable vessels, making arrangements with the ports of Ostend and Ramsgate, building the infrastructure - such as bunkering - as well as crewing the ferries once they start operating. It added: It was intended to start the service in mid-February but this has now been delayed until late March for operational reasons. This coincides with the Department for Transports Freight Capacity Purchase Agreement with Seaborne which is part of their preparations to increase ferry capacity in the unlikely event of a no-deal Brexit. Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Sir Ed Davey said: That the Government has reportedly signed a contract with a ferry company with no ferries pretty much sums up their farcical approach to the entire Brexit fiasco.   The Government could, and should, take the threat of a no-deal Brexit off the table. It is being used only to try and scaremonger people into backing their deal. It is now costing the country millions - it is inexcusable and people wont be fooled. And Labour MP Tonia Antoniazzi said: Never has it been clearer that our Government is selling us down the river over Brexit. A firm that has never run a ferry service before has been awarded a multi-million pound contract and they dont even have any ships. We know our ports arent ready for a no-deal disaster, but is hiring a firm thats never dealt with this kind of thing before really going to help  This idea should have been sunk before it saw the light of day. A Department for Transport spokesman added: This contract was awarded in the full knowledge that Seaborne Freight is a new shipping provider, and that the extra capacity and vessels would be provided as part of its first services. As with all contracts, we carefully vetted the companys commercial, technical and financial position in detail before making the award.

title: earl real life downton abbey
story: NewsEarl of real-le Downton Abbey stands for lelong seat in Parliament - and you dont get a voteGeorge Reginald Oliver Molyneux Herbert, the th Earl of Carnarvon, is one of  aristocrats who want to make your laws for up to £ a day in the worlds most elitist electionShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsGeorge Herbert, the th Earl of Carnarvon, lives at Highclere Castle - now famous as TVs Downton Abbey "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Tory Earl who owns the real-le Downton Abbey is standing for a lelong seat in Parliament - and the British public wont even get a vote. George Reginald Oliver Molyneux Herbert is one of  aristocrats competing in a hereditary peer by-election in the House of Lords. Only hereditary peers can stand in the bizarre poll, a hangover from attempts to reform the Lords, and only members of the House of Lords can vote. The winner will be able to shape laws and claim pound a day until they die or retire - a situation previously branded a mockery of our democracy. The -year-old th Earl of Carnarvon lives with his countess we in Highclere Castle on a ,-acre estate in Hampshire. The lavish house with a state dining room, library and smoking room was used as the home of the Crawley family in ITVs fictional period drama.   His ancestor the rd Earl remodelled the sprawling manor, whose origins date to AD, in the s into the stately home that is now famous around the world. And the th Earl practiced digging in its grounds before joining forces with Howard Carter to discover the tomb of Tutankhamun in Egypt. Tours of the estate cost pound a head while a Valentines Day tour with afternoon tea costs pound for a couple. In a manesto to fellow peers, the th Earl said owning his home has given him experience of small business, farming, tourism and countryside heritage matters that would help him in the House of Lords.  He added the residences renown gives him an international outlook to the world through Highcleres presence online. He also wrote he could bring experience from investing and working in software and technology, and promised to take part in committees and debates. But Shadow Cabinet Minister Jon Trickett said: When the ‘Earl of Downton Abbey’ has a greater chance of getting into Parliament than any one of the millions of working people of this country, you know our political system is simply not fit for purpose. With more people than ever wanting a say in how things are run, it’s simply not acceptable to choose our lawmakers by having  aristocrats compete for the votes of a few hundred other aristocrats. It’s time for a radical overhaul of how politics is done, so it works in the interests of the many, and not the few. The election is a hangover from Tony Blairs bid to modernise the House of Lords. Hereditary peers were mostly cast out in  but  remained as a compromise. That means when one dies or retires, remaining hereditary peers get first refusal on the seat, and only members of the House of Lords can vote. The latest election is being held to replace Tory Lord Skelmersdale, an Old Etonian who sat in the Lords for  years before his death in October.  Ten of the  candidates are Conservatives, five are independent crossbenchers and one, Lord Cadman, has not declared a party affiliation. Rival candidates include -year-old Lord Biddulph, whose entire manesto is the words always happy to serve, and Viscount Mountgarret, whose family own , acres of land devoted to game hunting in North Yorkshire. Other candidates include retired Navy commander the Earl of Effingham and state secondary school teacher Lord Hampton. Peers will be invited to cast their ballot in the opulent Queens robing room in the House of Lords on January . They can also vote by post. The by-election, expected to cost just over pound, to run, is the fourth of its kind since the start of . Darren Hughes, Chief Executive of the Electoral Reform Society, said earlier this year hereditary peer by-elections are an undemocratic farce and make mockery of our democracy. Downton Abbey creator Lord Fellowes is already a non-hereditary Tory peer after being elevated to the Lords by David Cameron in .  peers join the Lords - despite PMs promises By BEN GLAZE, Deputy Political Editor Some  new peers have been appointed to the House of Lords this year – despite Theresa May promising to slash the size of the bloated Second Chamber. Scottish National Party spokesman Tommy Sheppard said it was inexcusable successive governments had continued to make chummy political appointments to the Upper House, at an annual cost to the taxpayer of pound, per peer. The  new members in  included nine Conservatives, six crossbenchers, three from Labour and one from the Democratic Unionist Party, as well as three bishops.  The SNP does not take seats in the Lords on principle. Mr Sheppard said: The idea of an unelected legislature in the st Century is ridiculous enough, but for successive governments to continue to pile the Lords chamber full of chummy political appointments is inexcusable. The argument to consign this archaic and undemocratic chamber of political has-beens to the dustbin of history is long overdue. Last year, figures showed that each peer costs the taxpayer pound, per year and since then, no less than  Lords have been stuffed into the House.  Whilst many households and families across the UK spend the festive season worrying how to pay their food and fuel bills, unelected peers enjoy a pound tax-free daily allowance for as little as  minutes attendance.” However, a Lords spokesman said the overall number of members fell by  over the year to  because  members had left. It was on track to meet a target of , he added. He branded the pound, figure misleading, saying it represented the total Lords budget ided by the number of members, rather than reflecting the cost of each inidual peer to taxpayers. The Mirror has been campaigning to scrap the unelected House of Lords. The Earl of Carnarvon defended putting his hat in the ring saying:I hoped I could make a contribution to what helps us build icommunities, prosperity and rural sustainability. He said the job of the Lords was to offer authoritative views from the experience, expertise and personal distinction of its members, not challenge the Commons. He added: The Lords are appointed by a iety of routes whether political preference or through associations, which effectively marks this particular process. In the end the constituency of the House of Lords can lead to mediation with longer term views making contributions to thought and reflection which can give positive aspects to public le with less immediate partisan considerations.

story: NewsBrexit: Irish passport applications surge to , from UK in past yearThe number from England, Scotland and Wales soared by more than a fthShareByBen GlazeDeputy political editorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsMore and more Brits want Irish passports "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDemand for Irish passports has surged since the Brexit vote with almost , applications received from the UK this year. The number from England, Scotland and Wales soared by more than a fth compared to , Ireland’s Department of Foreign Affairs said. It comes as increasing number of Brits seek Irish citizenship - which means they can keep their rights to free movement around the EU after Brexit. Foreign affairs minister Simon Coveney said the total had surged since the June  Brexit vote. Some , applications were from Northern Ireland and , applications were received from Great Britain. These figures represent an increase of % and %, respectively, over  figures. Mr Coveney said: “It is important that the Passport Service continues to use technology in order to gain efficiencies and deliver the best possible service to the citizen.” In October it emerged Irelands UK embassy had received as many applications in the first half of  as the whole of .  Fine Gaels Neale Richmond, chairman of the Brexit committee in the Irish senate, at the time suggested the looming disaster of Brexit was pushing people to reclaim Irish citizenship. If there is a Brexit deal, EU and UK citizens will effectively keep their rights to move freely across borders until December . Butthere is no deal, visas are expected to be needed for long-term trips to the EU after  March . Short term holidays are expected to be visa-free. Who is eligible for Irish citizenship - and how to applyIrish passports are only available to Irish citizens. However, you can become an Irish citizen through birth or descentyou have an Irish parent or grandparent. To do this, you must apply to the Foreign Births Register. This costs €and you need to provide proof of residence, a copy of your passport, and yours and your grandparents original long-form birth certicates. You also need the signature of a witness who isnt related to you, who has to be one of a list of high standing professions in the community. Witnesses can include a bank manager, magistrate, doctor, clergyman or police officer. Once you have obtained Irish citizenship, you can then apply for an Irish passport. This costs € and again needs a host of documents to prove you are eligible.

title: kevin maguire predict annus horribilis
story: NewsopinionKevin Maguire: I predict an annus horribilis for Theresa May AND Donald TrumpThe only certainty is that the next year will be as uncertainShareCommentsByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsopinionIs Theresa May facing a terrible  "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPredictions may be a mug’s game in an era of shypolitical turmoil...but they’re also irresistible.So here Mystic Mag peers into his crystal ball to try and make sense of . The only certainty is that the next year will be as uncertain as the past three have proved. Theresa May’s Blackmail Brexit The corpse of the PM’s scam to make Britain poorer and weaker is still twitching after she postponed a vote that would have pronounced it formally dead.Buying Tory rebels with gongs and pretending it’s her way or no way, might lure some waverers back. Unprincipled Cabinet Minister Liam sly-as-a Fox claiming Brexit is - without her deal might tempt a few more to back it. And the DUP’s always biddable. My hunch is she’ll still lose in the Commons in the week of January . A panicky second referendum afterwards  I’m not so sure.   No Deal Catastrophe Spending billions of precious pounds buying everything from fridges to ferries is a scandalous waste of public money when the only thing MPs agree on is Britain won’t crash out of Europe. End of. Will we leave EU on March   Yes,May’s plot works. Though it’s worth recalling her former Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab thinks we’d be better off staying in than leaving on her lousy terms and Brexit paymaster Arron Banks would vote to remain in another referendum. No,May’s dodgy deal’s shot down. Suspending the Article  exit timetable would be required to sort out a better future.   Honest Referendum My favoured democratic way forward after the nailing of lies that there would be poundmillion a week freed for the NHS and Brexit would be easy were nailed.As former mandarin Martin Donnelly memorably argued we’re giving up a three-course meal for the promise of a packet of crisps.Yet a people’s vote is only possible not probable in . Just a fth of  MPs want to let us decide. General Election Hard to see how Jeremy Corbyn will get his  wish when Tory and DUP MPs could ditch May and her Brexit but avoid an election that could put Labour into power.Corbyn is preparing to initiate his constitutional no confidence vote in the Government late January or February. Win and it’s election on.   Tick-Tock Tedious Theresa May’s likely to be history this time next year after promising never to fight another election in order to survive this month’s Tory rebellion.Jeremy Hunt is favourite to replace her but Sajid Javid, Penny Mordaunt, Dominic Raab, Matt Hancock and Boris Johnson fancy their chances. Slow Lane Britain’s fallen from one of Europe’s fastest growing economies to among the slowest since the  Brexit vote. Much depends on what happens after March  yet wages are unlikely toto  values for years. Austerity Schools, Universal Credit, council housing, libraries, cops, fire – just about every precious public service – will continue to be squeezed.Even a much-hyped NHS poundbillion increase by  is far less than’s needed. The Tory era rise of .% since  was the lowest since the health service was created in , less than a fth of the Labour years. Jeremy Corbyn Uneasy murmurings among the Labour leader’s followers will get louder unless he opposes Brexit as a class issue when working people will be hurt most.He also needs to back a people’s vote and establish clear poll leads.Corbyn’s position is unchallengeable and he could finish in No  but, after four years, the personality cult is waning.   Splinter Labour Westminster’s waiting for a group of anti-Corbyn, pro-EU MPs led by Chuka Umunna and Chris Leslie to quit the Labour whip in Parliament. Talk is of up to a dozen after March. Six MPs have already gone rogue and a seventh, suspended liar Fiona Onasanya is threatening to stay as an MP evenjailed for perverting the course of justice.Defections and rows are poised to cost Labour seats. Liar, Liar, Trump’s Pants on Fire The net’s closing on lie machine Donald Trump but the shameless US President would survive impeachment as Republicans hold the Senate despite the House of Representatives falling to the Democrats.With Trump intending to run in , the opposition’s searching for a champion.Watch out for Bernie Sanders, Joe Biden, Elizabeth Warren Sherrod Brown and Beto O’Rourke. Oprah Winfrey and Angelina Jolie are teasing. Elizabeth the Last Backlashes over big public bills for Harry’s, and especially gormless Eugenie’s, royal nuptials could mean some uncomfortable scrutiny for the Royals in .The cause of the Windsors wasn’t helped by a poundmillion-a-year monarch sitting in front of a golden piano and lecturing us to pull together. On The Box Saving most or all the . million free TV licences for the over-s will be a  U-turn. The Tories aren’t strong enough to break another manesto promise. Far Right Off Their Heads Trump windbag Steve Bannon is deflating as his European “Movement” fails to lt off. Here the party’s over for purple poison Ukip and I predict in  fans of jailbird Stephen Yaxley-Lennon, aka football hooligan “Tommy Robinson”, will fall out over how much he’s making out of once naiumlve Tommyettes.

title: arron hough family pay tribute
story: NewsArron Hough: Family pay tribute to missing cruise ship entertainerArron Hough, , went overboard the Royal Caribbean liner Harmony of the Seas on Christmas Day, having posted a number of cryptic tweets just days beforeShareCommentsByElaine McCahillNews Reporter:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsArron Hough with his sister Emilie "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFamily and friends of Arron Hough have paid tribute to the missing cruise ship entertainer who went overboard on Christmas Day. It comes as the US Coastguard said it had ended the search for -year-old at about .pm on Thursday, two days after he reportedly went overboard in unknown circumstances. The -year-old was starring in a musical production of Grease on board Harmony of the Seas, the second-largest cruise ship in the world. Arrons sister Emilie paid tribute to her brother by changing her cover photo on Facebook to one of him leaping into the air during a dance routine.  She received hundreds of messages of support as another relative Rebecca Hough described him as our superstar alongside a clip of him performing. Back in June, Emilie had posted a picture of her giving Arron a kiss on the cheek after he landed the job on the cruise. She captioned the snap: Words can’t describe how proud I am of my not so little brother. I can’t believe how much you’ve grown and how far you’ve become! Seeing you graduate today was one of the proudest moments of my le! Can’t believe he’s leaving me for  month to join the Royal Caribbean and sail around the world! I love you. Arrons friends also posted messages with Lucy Devereaux writing: In our hearts always my love.  One wrote on Facebook: I’ve lost a part of my soul. I love you my Arron Hough. Another added: I am in total shock and disbelief. Praying that it isnt true. Mr Hough had been working on the bn Harmony of the Seas for only a few months, and his mum, Tracey Steel, wrote loving and supportive messages on his frequent Facebook posts while he was thousands of miles from home. After his first week on board Harmony of the Seas in October, she wrote: So so proud I could burst my beautul amazing boy. I Love You. Do you know Arron Hough  Email webnews@mirror. She wrote I love you son under his last post on December , which featured photos from Cozumel, Mexico. Last week, she wrote:If my love for you was stars it would light up the universe. Mr Hough, from Sunderland, disappeared from the Royal Caribbean ship on Christmas Day. The vessel, named Harmony Of The Seas, was  milesnorth-west of Aguadilla, Puerto Rico, at the time and was travelling to Philipsburg, St Maarten. The last CCTV footage available of Mr Hough showed him heading on to the ships deck at around am, according to a statement issued by Royal Caribbean. However, staff on board the ship only realised he was missing when he did not report to work later that day.  The United States Coast Guard was alerted to Mr Houghs disappearance at .pm, nearly  hours after hes believed to have gone missing. Royal Caribbean and the coast guard were unable to confirm how far the ship had travelled during that time. Just three days before he vanished, he wrote on Twitter: Beneath the water is beauty. Always look beneath the surface before you decide on things. In an earlier post on December , he wrote: Gonna kill someone f***ing hell. It is unclear what Mr Hough was referring to in his tweets, but he posted regular updates from his time on board the vessel and his off-days at sun-drenched destinations. Earlier this month, he posted a screen grab of a status pointing out that many people lead fake lives on social media, pretending they are leading happy and exciting existences. The original author of the status was not known, but it read: So.. social media is the killer of people.. the fake lives we live on social media pretending to all of our followers that were having such an amazing crazy ride when actually were not.. we struggle, we havehard times but we hide this with throwbacks and happy pictures we post.. which is fine to keep sadness on the DL.  The ,-ft long vessel was sailing from its home port in Florida to the French-Dutch island of Saint Martin, with , passengers and crew on board at the time of Houghs disappearance. CCTV showed him entering an area on Deck  - which includes a spa, the Royal Theater, a number of bars, restaurants and shops, and the main dining room - but he was never seen again. It appears no-one noticed Mr Hough was missing for several hours. He didnt show up for work, and CCTV was reviewed and a ship-wide search was launched. The circumstances of his fall were unclear. He is the fth person to go overboard on a cruise ship since November. None of the previous four people - including a British man - was found as most werent reported missing until hours later. Mr Hough is the second British man to go overboard from a Royal Caribbean cruise ship in a little over a month.  Jack Daniel Ackroyd, , from Cotgrave, Nottinghamshire, was working on the Adventure of the Seas when he vanished at about am on November . He was reported missing when he did not show up for work while the ship was at port in Cozumel, Mexico. A search was launched but he was not found. In September , one Harmony of the Seas crew member was killed and four were injured when a le boat broke loose and plunged from the fth deck during a security training exercise while it was docked in Marseille, France.

title: brit grandparents agonising choice bring
story: NewsBrit grandparents agonising choice as they bring ONE of murdered sons two children back to UKIan and Linda Simpson are finally bringing their six-year-old granddaughter back to the UK after her mum killed her dad - but they have had to leave her big brother behindShareCommentsBySophie Evans:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsIan and Linda Simpson are pictured beaming beside their granddaughter, Alice, before boarding a train to Shanghai "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo British grandparents are finally bringing their murdered sons six-year-old daughter back to the UK - but have had to leave her big brother behind. Ian and Linda Simpson were seen beaming with joy beside their granddaughter, Alice, after signing an out-of-court agreement to bring her to live in Britain. They agreed to pay more than pound, to the family of their grandchildrens Chinese mum - who brutally stabbed their son, Michael, to death last year. Last night, they were preparing to fly back with little Alice. But the youngsters homecoming is filled with heartache - because Ian and Linda have been forced to leave their eight-year-old grandson, Jack, behind.   The desperate pair, who continue to fight for custody of the two siblings, had been faced with the agonising choice to bring just Alice back - or neither child. This is because Jacks Chinese grandparents, who live in the northwestern city of Nanzhang, are refusing to give the boy up, The Mail on Sunday reports. On Boxing Day, as his gran Hu De Xiu packed a bag up for his little sister, the youngster reportedly wept and pleaded with her: Don’t let Alice go. We are overjoyed to bring Alice home but it breaks our hearts to leave Jack behind, Ian, now married to a second we, told the newspaper yesterday. Linda cried and asked me, How can we wrench them apart    He added that, in the end, he and his ex-we had to choose between bringing Alice home or walking away without either of their grandchildren. We could have lost them both for ever, he said. Ian and Lindas son Michael was killed in March  when he was kned by his estranged we, Weiwei Fu, in a jealous rage at his Shanghai apartment. The Next executive, who had met and married Fu after moving to China before they split up, had planned a university education for Alice and Jack. He had taken the youngsters around the world and gave them a western view, retired business project consultant Ian said in an interview earlier this year.   He added at the time said: “We lost our son and feel we can’t lose the children as well. They’re too precious... We can give them the le Michael wanted for them. We’d make sure they stayed in touch with their Chinese relatives.” Ian and Linda, who have spent more than pound, in their bid to get custody of Alice and Jack, spent time with their grandson in Nanzhang last week. They played with him at a hotel restaurant, as Fus parents looked on. Devastatingly, the two childrens Chinese relatives have allegedly told them that their parents are working abroad and that Michael abandoned them. But in reality, the father was stabbed to death by their mother, who is now serving le in prison after being locked up for murder this summer.   Ian, of Hartest, Suffolk, said earlier this year: That’s the lie they’ve been given but they’ll find out eventually. It’s terrible. He added that the kids were living in a one-bedroom flat containing five people, including their grandparents and cousin, in a small town. The granddad and Linda had previously enjoyed a close relationship with Alice and Jack. But after their sons murder, they were allegedly refused contact. The pair launched a heartbreaking battle for custody, which saw Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt raise the case on a visit to Beijing in July. Supporters also raised thousands to help the family. Ian and Linda ended up paying pound, in cash to Fus relatives.   They have reached an agreement that there will be weekly phone calls between Alice and Jack, as well as annual visits, the Mail on Sunday reports. Now, as they prepare to bring their granddaughter back to the UK, they are determined to keep up their fight until Jack can join them too. They say Alice is already missing her big brother. She has been amazingly brave but there have been moments when she has been in tears asking for her brother, Ian said. The grandparents have been supported in their battle by the Foreign Office.

title: fifty shades gday irish sugar
story: NewsFty Shades of G’day: Irish sugar baby could topple Australian government after racy textsAustralian minister and married father-of-one Andrew Broad allegedly compared himself to James Bond and sent sexually suggestive messages to sugar baby Amy Keating from DublinShareCommentsByAmber HicksSylvia Pownall:,  DEC NewsAmy Keating from Dublin has been named by Australian media as the sugar baby who minister Andrew Broad was messaging"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA married politician has been caught up in a scandal dubbed “Fty Shades Of G’day” after racy texts he sent to a sugar baby were exposed. Australian minister Andrew Broad, , is said to have told the Irish woman in her s: I know how to f*** my woman, along with other sexually suggestive remarks after meeting via an online dating website. The woman has been named by media in Australia as Amy Keating, , from Dublin. She is said to have used the online alias of “Sweet Sophia Rose” on the Seeking Arrangement dating site, reports the Irish Mirror. Her father has since branded her a bloody eejit over the drama and said she is as naive as they come, at times.   Amy and Mr Broad are said to have exchanged online messages before the politician flew to Hong Kong to meet at an upmarket sky bar boasting city views. While there, Amy claims the dad-of-one compared himself to James Bond, put his hand on her knee and moaned about the menu prices. She said the incident went no further than the restaurant because she felt uncomfortable and left early.She also claims he lied about his age saying he was , seven years younger than his real age. Later that evening, it is alleged she sent a text to the politician telling him to pay her “the allowance” of , Hong Kong dollarsinto her Paypal account or  she would go public. She reportedly stated: “I’m fully aware of how much more I could getI went public to the papers with my story”. It is understood that he did not pay her, but instead referred the text to Australian police, who said the matter was outside their jurisdiction. Amy then went public and her claims were published in gossip magazine New Idea. After the messages were revealed, Mr Broad quit his position as Assistant Minister to the Deputy Prime Minister. The furore has also threatened to bring down the government, which is facing claims it knew about the messages two weeks before they were exposed.   According to The Sydney Morning Herald, Prime Minister Scott Morrison’s office were aware the messages were the subject of potential legal proceedings. Amys claims were published in New Idea magazine along with some of the messages the pair are said to have sent before they met. It reports in one message, Mr Broad said: “I’m an Aussie lad, I know how to ride a horse, fly a plane and f*** my woman. My intentions are completely dishonourable.” She said another text message from him read: “I’ve booked a flashy room to seduce you back to.” When she told him she found Australian accents sexy, he is said to have replied: “I pull you close, run my strong hands down your back, softly kiss your neck and whisper ‘G’day mate’.” Amy’s father has now defended her, claiming “she is not a lady of the night by any manner or means”, and would never resort to blackmail. He said she has a masters level education, and is working in Hong Kong after being transferred there by her company.  Speaking to the Sunday Independent, he said: “She has made many a mistake. “She is as naive as they come, at times. But I am glad that she did what she did at the restaurant. “But do I think she covered herself in glory afterwards  Absolutely not. I thought she was a bloody eejit. An absolute idiot. Meanwhile, a spokeswoman for Seeking Arrangement has said the site will not be taking action against Amy for going public. Spokeswoman Brook Urick said: “There weren’t any terms of use broken here, they both were using the site in a way we deem appropriate. She suggested Amy’s actions “speaks to the climate of women after the #MeToo movement, they don’t want to see that anymore and they’re going to take control as much as they can”. Several women are believed to have come forward since the story broke claiming National Party MP Mr Broad behaved “inappropriately”. Australia’s Herald Sun newspaper reported three women contacted party officials over the past  months about alleged inappropriate behaviour online and in bars. Mr Broad declined to clary whether his trip was on government business or private and whether he covered his expenses or accepted part of his travel as a gt from others.

title: frugal mum buys nothing new
story: NewsFrugal mum buys nothing new for second year running after becoming fed-up with wasteApart from a school unorm for her daughter, Katie Musgrave, , has only purchased food, nappies and essentials throughout the whole of ShareCommentsByJohn BettAbigail OLeary:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsKatie Musgrave, Britains most frugal mum who vowed to go a whole year without buying anything new "Get money updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA frugal mum has bought nothing new for a whole YEAR after becoming fed-up with waste. Apart from a school unorm for her daughter, Katie Musgrave, , has only purchased food, nappies and essentials throughout the whole of . She originally pledged to change her spending lestyle after growing sick of the amount of barely-used equipment, clothing and toys that were being stored in her home. And on December , , she pledged to only buy pre-loved items for herself or her three kids Eliza, five, Ariadne, three and Daniel,  months. In , Katie managed to survive the whole year by buying every item preloved except for buying her daughters a pair of shoes in summer - and this year shes done even better.   The devoted mum said she managed to go the whole year without buying anything - except for a school unorm for her daughter, Ariadne. The devoted mum has even had a frugal festive period, and has gted family and friends with home made food hampers. Although she admits she did splurge on one item - a pair of socks for her mother-in-law, Elizabeth Musgrave, , which cost pound. Katie, a GP registrar from Loddiswell, Devon, said: Weve had another year of not buying anything new for the children. This Christmas weve been making presents which we will give to family members and friends.   The children have been making gts and things for their bedrooms, things dont have to cost a lot to have meaning. For Christmas I bought both daughters a puzzle, and one of them got a microscope and the other has a spirograph. Theyve also got clothes and shoes, all preloved. My newborn has got a push walker - a little dog with a jumper on. Katie, who has this year had her third child with GP husband Chris, , managed the whole year with only one blip. She bought a new school unorm for her youngest daughter, who started education this year. She continued: Weve mostly stuck to nothing new, my daughter started school so we had to buy a unorm. Id say weve spent maybe pound in the whole year, Im sure I have saved at least pound over the course of the year. Weve still bought food and everyday essentials, but we use charity shops mostly.   Its a habit that weve gotten into, you can find pretty much anything in charity shops or on eBay, you dont need to buy things new. The children are always excited when I come home, I bought my daughter a jumper with alpacas on it and she loves it. It doesnt have to cost much for it to matter to them. Katie said that with just a little effort they were able to live a le better than when they were more frivolously spending money. But when it comes to Christmas day they will be having a traditionally festive meal, but theyre still debating over Turkey or Goose. She said: Were still deciding, but we will be having a traditional Christmas with family. Weve put together a hamper of food and weve got my mother-in-law a pair of socks. They were a certain kind so I bought them brand new, they were pound.   Katie changed her lestyle and became compelled to act after she was shocked at how expensive it was raising small children. story: NewsTeenager left blinded when egg explodes in her face after cooking it in microwaveCourtney Wood, , still does not have full sight back in her left eye following the incident on Boxing DayShareCommentsByLouise Elliott:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsCourtney Wood was cooking breakfast on Boxing Day when the incident occurred "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenager was left temporarily blind after a microwaved egg exploded in her face. Courtney Wood, , has been without sight in her left eye following the traumatic incident, the Stoke Sentinel reports. She was making breakfast on Boxing Day when she decided to cook an egg in a microwave, something she had done a number of times before. The egg exploded in her face without warning after she took it out of the microwave oven, leaving her with burns and painful blisters. The care assistant from Newcastle has now issued a warning to others about the dangers. She said: On Boxing Day morning I was cooking myself some breakfast. I had put some bacon under the grill and then I put an egg in a jug with a bit of water - as I have done before - and popped it in the microwave for a minute. By this point I couldnt see and I was screaming in pain, she continued. My friend came round straightaway and he called  who told me to go straight to AE. Medics at the Royal Stoke University Hospital treated her with morphine and gauze. story: NewsUK could set-up Far East military bases to become global player after BrexitDefence Secretary Gavin Williamson said new military bases could also be sited in the CaribbeanShareCommentsByMark ChandlerAndrew Woodcock:,  DEC NewsThe Army could be heading to new bases after Brexit "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe UK could set-up new military bases in the Far East and Caribbean in a bid to become a true global player after Brexit, the Defence Secretary has claimed. Oppostion MPS immediately slammed the comments, accusing him of ignorance of military strategy and warning Brexit was making Britain a laughing stock. But, despite the huge problems besetting Theresa Mays deal, Mr Williamson insisted Brits should be much more optimistic about our future as we exit the European Union.  Mr Williamson claimed putting troops on standby to help out with Brexit was just good sensible planning to make sure that everything runs as smoothly as possible. He said: This is our biggest moment as a nation since the end of the Second World War, when we can recast ourselves in a dferent way, we can actually play the role on the world stage that the world expects us to play. Mr Williamson told the Sundayhe wanted establish a UK presence not just in the Far East but also in the Caribbean as well. He did not name possible locations, but a source said new bases, supply ships and equipment, housing service and maintenance staff, could be set-up in Singapore or Brunei in the South China Sea. They could also be sited at Montserrat or Guyana in the Caribbean within the next couple of years. Mr Williamson said: I am very much looking at how can we get as much of our resources forward based, actually creating a deterrent but also taking a British presence. We are looking at those opportunities not just in the Far East but also in the Caribbean as well.  He said there would be a political sht after Brexit, seeing the UK building deeper relationships with Australia, Canada, New Zealand, Caribbean states and nations across Africa. He predicted these countries would look to the UK for the moral leadership, the military leadership and the global leadership. The Defence Secretary said recent research showed Brits under-estimated the potential for UK global influence. title: new years eve 2018 map
story: NewsNew Years Eve : Map reveals when world celebrates the start of Revellers could even fit in two parties, beginning in Samoa before seeing the final fireworks around the USAShareCommentsByMark Chandler:,  DEC NewsSydney will celebrate New Years Eve at pm GMT on Monday "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA stunning new map reveals when everywhere in the world celebrates the start of New Years Eve. The interactive graphic charts December  parties from the very first firework in Samoa until the dawn of  on the US atolls of Baker and Howland Islands. And the timings mean die-hard revellers could even cram in the worlds first and last New Years Eve parties - but onlytheyre willing to fly  miles. Analytics experts at Esri UK have put together the map, plotting the course of s arrival in Greenwich Mean Time .  Christmas Island and Samoa are the first to see in the new year, with their clocks hitting midnight at am GMT on Monday. From there, New Zealand will welcome  from am GMT before most of Australia joins the party two hours later. China says goodbye to  from pm GMT, with spectacular firework displays expected in Beijing and Hong Kong.   New Delhi will be marking the event from .pm GMT, with Moscow joining at pm. And big European cities like Madrid, Paris and Rome will see midnight pass a full hour before the Brits. Americans, meanwhile, have to wait until at least am GMT before they can celebrate in earnest.   And the final flourish will be on outlying islands around the US like Baker and Howland at pm GMT, although, since no one lives there, it is likely to go unheralded. Jessica Houghton, technical research consultant at Esri UK, explained: The New Year’s Eve map is a fun way of helping explain GMT and shows how people around the globe will be celebrating and welcoming in  at dferent times. “Esri’s mapping and analytics software is currently used by millions of people around the world to visualise data using interactive maps, providing them with key insights and the ability to make the right decision first time.   And Professor Charles Withers, Geographer Royal for Scotland, said it was certainly possible to see in the New Year twice thanks to the worlds dferent time zones. He said: Because of the ision of the world into time zones, and our measurement of the world in terms of longitude, there is a line,  degrees longitude from Greenwich – the International Date Line or ‘line of demarcation’ – where consecutive days and dates meet.   The line has no legal status and, in fact, does not run as a straight line, north to south at  degrees from Greenwich, but curves in and out to reflect dferent countries’ interests.But it is possible to cross it and ‘gain’ a day – or cross in the other direction and so ‘lose’ a day.And yes, because this is so, you could, with the help of appropriate transport, have more than one New Year’s party.”

title: animal lover layla made sure citys needy dogs were not forgotten at christmas
story: A kind-hearted schoolgirl produced her own calendars to raise money for her local dog shelter.Layla Whitlam, , from Tayport, has taken an interest in helping animals in need and decided to go the extra mile over the festive period.She painted dog calendars, with all the money raised going towards buying goods for Dundee’s Brown Street Kennels.Layla’s mum Ashley, , a catering assistant, said: “She loves animals but unfortunately we’re pretty full at home.“We have eight guinea pigs, a hamster, two turtles, a dog and a cat.“For the last couple of years, we’ve been going along to Brown Street Kennels at Christmas because it’s the one nearest to us. We handed in treats at Christmas last year but nothing on the scale of this year.”Layla managed to raise £ from selling her calendars to family, teachers and everyone on her street.Ashley said: “She hand-painted each calendar and sold them for £..“Each one was unique depending on what the person asked for – there wasn’t a single calendar the same.”Layla worked on the calendars every night after school from November onwards.Her mum said the youngster always wants to do her best to help any creatures who need it.Ashley added: “When she sees an animal in need, she wants to help them and doesn’t want to let them go.“We went to Asda to buy the food and she scanned everything herself on the self-service tills.“She bought something for every type of dog at the shelter – food for older dogs, special food for puppies, a crate of puppy milk and even food for dogs with sensitive tummies.”Despite the house already being full of pets, Layla received a surprise when her new hamster Elizabeth was welcomed on Christmas morning.Ashley added: “My sister bought her it a couple of weeks ago and hid her at home until Christmas Day.”Layla now has her eye on potentially going into business with a dog rescue-style company.“She wants to have a company where both of us go around in a van and help the dogs on the streets,” said Ashley.

We make a real event of it.“The dook is short because the water is cold – but we always have live music. All the money gets put back into the club because we are a charity.“A lot of people from abroad sign up for the dook – some have come from Israel, Canada and Mexico. It’s fantastic.“It’s about community spirit and you can never be without that. It’s a fun day, you never know what kind of weather you are going to get.”The dook has been held in the Ferry since  and has never been cancelled – even in , when participants had to break the ice before they could enter the water.The event starts at am, when registration opens, with music provided by James Clark.There will also be a fancy dress parade and competition, as well as a carnival throughout the day. Monieth Pipe Band will be in attendance and the dookers will enter the water at .am.It costs £ to take part and participants will each get a T-shirt, a certicate and a hot drink.Also taking place on the day is the Arbroath Loony Dook.Ryan Taylor, chairman of the Angus Cancer Research Committee, which organises the event, said: “The dook has been established for nine years.“Our committee started it up – it is purely done for Cancer Research.“Generally we have - people participating each year.“My experience of it is that when you are in the water, it is not too bad – it’s once you get out and into the wind that you become a bit uncomfortable.”Bathers enter the water at .pm, led by a piper, on the beach between the Signal Tower Museum and the RNLI boathouse.It costs £ to sign up and participants get a Cancer Research dook T-shirt.Ryan said people can take part in fancy dressthey wish, or wear the official dook attire.The dook in Carnoustie, at the seafront, is organised by the town’s rugby club.Kath Edmond, one of the organisers, said: “This is our th year. We get about  to  people on the day.“A lot of kids and a lot of our junior section go in.”The dook was organised by Rod Bruce and Peter Christie who, on a whim, decided to do a sponsored dook for the club.It was two years before other people decided to join in.The dook costs £ to register and is at midday.The money will go towards The Boars Hut, for all the groups who use the school playing fields.Participants are invited back to the club afterwards for food and drink.

title: buy one get one free set sail with the tele on a luxury cruise to norway and the scottish isles departing from dundee
story: Tele readers will be able to enjoy the best sights Norway and Scotland have to offer when the paper sets sail on its very own cruise adventure.The exclusive Tele voyage on the majestic Magellan cruise ship  will depart on a nine-night tour around some of the most breath-taking scenery in the world.With up to , passengers, the glamorous ship will visit awe-inspiring fjords and some of Scotland’s stunning islands.A convenient departure from the Port of Dundee means you can look forward to leaving the hassles of airports behind and get straight into holiday mode.The journey evokes nostalgic memories of the days when The Tele#s parent company ran a famous shipping line in the s.There will be plenty of entertainment on board as well during the special trip # all organised by The Tele#s owners DC Thomson and ship operator Cruise and Maritime Voyages.Fresh delights will await every day as a dedicated team of expert chefs and attentive restaurant staff serve up delicious meals and a luxurious evening dining experience with up to five courses.Magellan, named after the great explorer Ferdinand Magellan, offers an incredible iety of activities within its ftframe, including a show lounge, pubs, coffee shops, casino and shopping galleria.The Tele Magellan voyage departs from Dundee on June  , and arrives back in Greenock  days later # after taking in sights including Flam, Bergen and Portree.While best known these days for its industry-leading publishing work, DC Thomson has a long and proud association with the sea.Following his success in business, William Thomson II looked to the seas and purchased a stake in a sailing ship.His involvement escalated over the years when he purchased more vessels.Eventually, with a fleet of , the Thomson family was responsible for one of the most invaluable shipping firms in the world and provided essential aid to South Africa during the Boer War.Andrew Thomson, chairman of DC Thomson, said: “It’s wonderful to see DC Thomson realigning with its heritage by ing to the seas.“When William Thomson established the Thomson Shipping Line in the th century I’m sure he didn’t contemplate that over  years later DC Thomson would be transporting passengers by ship around the Scottish Isles and Norway.“This kind of ersication of the business is a great fit for DC Thomson.”Craig Houston, head of enterprise for DC Thomson Media, said: “Working with Cruise  Maritime Voyages to bring this highly desirable sailing route to DC Thomson Travel customers has been a pleasure.“We’re excited to be offering such a special route with a trusted partner and we can’t wait to hear what our passengers say about this amazing trip.”

title: dundee people multi sensory penguin hunt show has children all a flutter with excitement
story: Local little ones had a fantastic time helping to find Philip the penguin at an interactive theatre performance.Kids aged two to six headed to Dundee Rep to take part in the Flutter performance which took them on a journey through a world of winter snow.The show combined puppetry, music and dferent materials to create a multi-sensory show for small hands, eyes, ears and noses.The young ones were treated to a snowy performance by Christie Mitchell and Arran Howie before they were invited on to the stage to meet Philip the penguin and play in the snow with the actresses.Christie said: “Early years audiences are probably the greatest and most honest audiences to perform in front of.“They get so involved throughout the show, shouting out funny one- liners, and by the end they are itching to get up on the set to play with the snow and meet Philip the penguin.“It is fantastic when parents come up to us at the end and say ‘my -month-old child has just sat for  minutes without losing concentration – it’s a miracle’.“It is nice to be told you are so captivating.”Amanda Cherry, from Perth, took her three-year-old daughter Ella to the performance and thought it was great to see something a bit dferent.She said: “I didn’t know what to expect but the two actresses were really good.“It was great to take Ella to see something a bit dferent that she could get involved in.”Broughty Ferry mum Victoria Spendf took along four-year-old twins Brody and Elliot and thinks it is important to get kids into theatre from a young age.She added: “We all absolutely loved the show. It was lovely to see the boys so engaged and joining in with the performance.“I would definitely recommend parents to come along to shows like this as I think it is very important to introduce your children to the arts as early as possible.”Linda Murray also enjoyed the show with three-year-old Arran but the trip may have become a bit more expensive for her.She said: “It was fantastic, Arran really enjoyed it. It is definitely his cup of tea getting to go up on stage and get interaction from the performers. However, now I have to go out and buy him his very own Philip the penguin.”

title: dundee v st johnstone ending year with a victory is paramount for dark blues
story: Paul McGowan says it’s “paramount” Dundee finish off a miserable  with a victory as they welcome St Johnstone to Dens Park today.The winter break beckons after the final whistle and the Dark Blues midfielder wants to be heading into the time off by ending on a positive note.And,results where go their way, that could see them off the bottom of the Premiership table going into the second half of the campaign.The Perth Saints, however, have been in mean form of late – winning seven of their last  and keeping eight clean sheets in the process.Dundee’s home form makes good reading, too, though, and ‘Gowser’ has called on a repeat performance of the battling - draw against Livingston on Wednesday.He accepts, however, they’ll need to provide better service to the strikersthey are to get the win they crave.He told the Tele: “We want to finish with a win, it’s paramount we finish the year with a victory.“Going into a week or so off with a win will do our confidence no harm at all.“It will be a tough game and we will need to battle like we did on Wednesday to get anything from it.“That’s us four unbeaten going into another tough game against St Johnstone.“I feelwe play like we did on Wednesday, starting with a clean sheet is always the way forward andwe can start scoring goals again we’ll win games.“Our end ball, though, has to be better into the strikers. We need to give them something to prey on.“We’re getting into good areas out wide but the final ball is either too much or not beating the first man.#He added: #We know what we will get from St Johnstone, it will be another tough game, like Livingston.“I just hope we have turned a corner now.“I felt we looked solid, we worked for each other, filling in for each other and it was enjoyable to play in that game.“The three before Wednesday weren’t great but that was back to our old selves.”In the past three seasons, it’s been all level in the battles between the top-flight’s Tayside teams with four wins apiece in the last eight.And the -year-old expects yet another close encounter.He said: “It’s been mixed against St Johnstone for us lately.“Tommy Wright’s brought in some good players and they are doing well this season.“Nearly every season you say that – you think they are going to hit a blip but they just don’t.“They can grind out results but they’ve been playing good football as well and can mix it up.“It will be tough and we need to be at it.”After defeats to Kilmarnock, Aberdeen and Celtic, McGowan feels the point against Livingston on Boxing Day is a step back in the right direction.“We earned a clean sheet from a tough game – Livi kept launching balls and we had to stand up and be counted,” he said.“I felt we did that well but we lacked the cutting edge, the final ball when getting into good areas. It’s a step back in the right direction and, hopefully, be a good point in the end.“Livingston’s gameplan was to go direct and put balls into the box to make things hard for us but I felt we stood up to it very well, I can’t think of them having a clear chance.“A draw was probably a fair result but I felt we were the better team.Hopefully, it’s a good point come the end of the season.”

title: former dundee favourite gary harkins moves to partick thistle and could face united this weekend
story: Two former Dundee midfielders have completed moves to Championship outfits.Dens cult hero Gary Harkins left Queen of the South this week and has signed up for a second spell at Partick Thistle.Jags boss Gary Caldwell has secured the -year-old on an -month deal and he’s now expected to make his debut against old rivals Dundee United at Tannadice on Saturday.Also on the move is Nicky Low, who left Derry City at the end of the Irish season in November. title: takeover talk was none of our business says dundee united defender
story: Defender Callum Booth says the Dundee United takeover and the speculation in the run-up to it was never a big topic of conversation in the dressing-room.And the full-back admits there was much more gossip in the squad after Csaba Laszlo’s departure at the end of December.However, he concedes what new American owner Mark Ogren does once the transfer window opens next week will be grabbing the attention of him and his team-mates.“I would say we were more focused on the speculation surrounding the club when we didn’t have a manager,” said the -year-old former Partick Thistle man.“Then that was what all the players were talking about. It was ‘who do you think it’s going to be  I’ve heard this or that’ and stuff like that.“I think with regards to the owners or the chairman, we don’t really see them that much on a day-to-day basis.“And the club has been running along smoothly, so it was not something we were speaking about too much.“There was a lot of talk about it in the week or so leading up to the takeover being confirmed last week, so it was mentioned but not all that much to be honest.”Now, though, Booth is keen to see just how much Minnesota-based Ogren is going to give manager Robbie Neilson to further strengthen the squad for the second half of the season.“January and the transfer window is coming and it will be interesting what happens, though it’s hard to say what will. We’ll get a view of the chairman’s ambition then and see what he does.“For us, Mike Martinwas a great guy but we didn’t see him too much and it will be the same with the new owner. We’ll talk about it a little bit but not too much and we just concentrate on the games coming up.”That focus on games made Booth well aware of the importance of United getting a win when Falkirk visited last Saturday.He believes the three points taken from that - victory were vital.“Obviously we’d not won in three games, so it was vital to get back to winning ways, especially at home.“Our last home performance against Ayr was disappointing, so it was huge to get the three points and I thought we played well and created a load of chances.“We probably should have been at least - up by the time injury time came and we gave away the penalty they scored from.“We were a bit slack for it and it meant the last few minutes were kind of ‘oh no’, but we managed to hold out pretty comfortably in the end and deserved the win.“It should have been dead and buried before that and I was really disappointed at not getting the clean sheet because we had defended really well during the game.“Overall, it was a good performance and a good win. We created good openings and we need to learn from that and put away more chances when we’re creating them like we did.”Booth also believes it was important United got back to imposing their passing game on teams again, just as they’d done in the draw at Inverness a week earlier.“That’s two good performances in a row. Four points from a home game against Falkirk and a trip to Inverness is not a bad .“We had a little dip and the Ayr United game took us by shock.“We didn’t really recover the week after down at Morton where it was a pretty poor performance but we feel back on track and long may it continue.”

title: wasted emergency services spent a fortnight attending hoax calls
story: Tayside#s emergency fire and ambulance crews have spent nearly a fortnight responding to hoax calls over the past four years, the Tele can reveal.Hundreds of calls have been made to both services which have led to a turn-out of staff, only for them to find it was malicious.Firefighters have spent more than , minutes – a total of  hours or more than  days – responding to such incidents since -.The majority of those calls involved fire alarms being activated deliberately, but they have also attended  reports about dangerous buildings, crashes and people in distress.In -, crews spent more time attending hoax calls than any of the previous two years, at more than , minutes.Between April and November this year, the figure stood at , minutes.Terry Whyte, local representative for the Fire Brigades Union , said crews are working hard to inform children about the implications of making   calls.He said: “The FBU has been working with the fire and rescue service to try to drive this down.“It’s down to education, such as going into schools and teaching kids about how important it is.“Our officers could be tied up with something  when there is a much more serious incident going on where.“We are constantly out speaking to kids about the dangers of making these kind of calls.“If there’s a specic area that we’re getting these calls from, then we’ll go out to it.“We certainly won’t be slowing down in trying to stop it happening for good.”Meanwhile, paramedics in Tayside have also been on the receiving end of malicious calls – most frequently in Dundee.Ambulance staff in the city have spent a total of , minutes responding to hoax calls since - – equal to about  hours, or more than two days. vw, px"  And figures suggest that - is on track to be the worst year of the last four – with more than  minutes already spent on hoax incidents since April, more than the whole of - and just short of figures from - or -.Callers have ly reported patients having breathing problems, traumatic injuries, chest pains, burns, drowning and even stabbing or gunshot wounds, during their malicious calls.A Scottish Ambulance Service spokesman said: “Anyone who calls  without a genuine need is potentially putting lives at risk by tying up valuable resources that could be needed for a le-threatening call.“When appropriate, malicious or nuisance callers are reported to the police.“However, in many cases, the call is a result of a social issue rather than malice and the patient may still need assistance.“In these cases, the relevant agencies are advised so appropriate care can be provided.”A Scottish Government spokesman said: “We condemn hoax calls to our emergency services. These are not victimless pranks and they can potentially distract vital resources and attention away from those who are in le-threatening situations.“The Scottish Ambulance Service has been clear that when appropriate, malicious or nuisance callers are reported to the police.”
